channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: How an Indian Stranger’s Blood Saved a Young Pakistani in Delhi
item.description: A Pakistani American author recalls the bonhomie of Indians in Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By SHAHAN MUFTI
item.media:description: Flags of India and Pakistan flying alongside each other near South Block in New Delhi, which houses several government offices, July 13, 2001.

item.title: Kenya’s Deputy President Must Attend Most of Hague Trial
item.description: The International Criminal Court reversed a ruling that would have allowed William Ruto, the deputy president, to be present only on key occasions.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Kenya's deputy president, William Ruto, in the Hague last week.

item.title: Norway Rejects U.S. Request to Help Destroy Syrian Chemical Weapons
item.description: The Foreign Ministry in Oslo cited regulatory constraints and time pressures after mulling the request for several weeks.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: North Korea Hands Over 6 South Korean Detainees
item.description: Little was known about the men released Friday, and South Korea said it would interrogate them to find out how they had gotten to the North.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Human Rights Activist Sima Samar
item.description: Sima Samar, one of the foremost human rights activists from Afghanistan, talks about the challenges Afghan women face.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Right Livelihood Award Foundation
item.media:description: Sima Samar, human rights activist and chairperson of the Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Court Upholds Life Sentence for Bo Xilai
item.description: Though the fallen Chinese politician’s story has been full of twists, the High People’s Court in the city of Jinan did exactly what everyone expected it would do.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Police officers changing shifts outside the courthouse in Jinan where Bo Xilai's appeal was rejected.

item.title: Germany and France Propose Talks With U.S. to Rein In Spying
item.description: The offer was an attempt to defuse a trans-Atlantic dispute over eavesdropping by the United States that has hurt its relations with Europe and prompted calls to suspend trade talks.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel at a news conference in Brussels on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: U.S. Pledges $1 Million to Help Relocate Iranian Exiles
item.description: The exiles, who are considered terrorists in Iran, were originally permitted to seek refuge in Iraq by Saddam Hussein after the 1979 Iranian revolution.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Algeria: Troops Find Large Cache of Weapons Near Libyan Border
item.description: The weapons, which were found in Illizi in southern Algeria and were thought to belong to militants, included 100 antiaircraft missiles, hundreds of antihelicopter rockets and rocket-propelled grenades.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Investigators Reopen Case of Missing British Child
item.description: The case, one of the most notorious recent child-abduction cases in Europe, was formally closed in 2008.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: In Quake-Prone Israel, Public Is Advised to Take Cover, This Time Outside
item.description: As recent tremors raise fears, a new safety campaign instructs people who have long been told to rush indoors during a rocket attack to do the opposite during a big earthquake.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Dispute Over Canadian Senators’ Expenses Balloons Into Larger Political Scandal
item.description: The scandal has prompted a debate over whether the Senate, an appointed body, should continue to exist.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada took questions Wednesday in the House of Commons.

item.title: Memo From Japan: With a Plant’s Tainted Water Still Flowing, No End to Environmental Fears
item.description: Recent accidents have raised questions about whether the environment is facing new dangers more than two and a half years after the original disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER and HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Tokyo Electric Power Company, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, where releases of contaminated water may not slow until at least 2015.

item.title: Hardships Mounting for Refugees Inside Syria
item.description: With millions displaced inside the country and an estimated $30 billion in infrastructure damage, the humanitarian crisis dwarfs any conceivable aid effort and could set Syria’s development back decades.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Indignation Over U.S. Spying Spreads in Europe
item.description: Politicians across the spectrum in Germany and in Europe were indignant at the apparent violation of trust between friends.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: News Analysis: Drone Issue Hovers More Than Ever, Even as Strikes Ebb
item.description: Scrutiny of drones has been driven by pressure from advocacy groups, media leaks and demands in both the United States and Pakistan for greater transparency in the program.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pressure from multiple sides has increased the volume of the debate over drone strikes.

item.title: Allegation of U.S. Spying on Merkel Puts Obama at Crossroads
item.description: Officials in the Obama administration say that the National Security Agency, in its push to build a global data-gathering network, has rarely weighed the long-term political costs of some of its operations.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, fourth from left in the back row, with other leaders at a summit meeting in Brussels on Thursday. Tension with the United States has built since German officials were given evidence of cellphone monitoring of her.

item.title: French to Strike, but This Time Owners Call It
item.description: A group representing France’s professional soccer owners plans to cancel matches next month to protest a tax on salaries of more than one million euros.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: A French Ligue 1 match last weekend. The owners of France’s professional soccer teams plan to protest a tax on salaries of more than one million euros.

item.title: 1 Dead and 40 Hurt in Mexican Candy Factory Explosion
item.description: An explosion inside a candy factory in the border city of Ciudad Juarez on Thursday left one person dead and at least 40 injured, Mexican authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Boxing Champion Throws His Hat in a New Ring
item.description: Vitali Klitschko, who is the reigning World Boxing Council heavyweight champion and leads an opposition political party in Ukraine, declared his candidacy for president of Ukraine in an election scheduled for 2015.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: A Game of Shark and Minnow
item.description: The shell of a forsaken ship has become a battleground in a struggle that could shape the future of the South China Sea and, to some extent, the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF HIMMELMAN
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson/VII, for The New York Times
item.media:description: A grounded World War II-era ship manned by eight Filipino servicemen who are supposed to keep China in check.

item.title: Response to a City’s Smog Points to a Change in Chinese Attitude
item.description: Rising concern about pollution in China and a more active response signal that some officials are serious about tackling the chronic problem.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Government workers moved signs to block roads amid heavy fog in Harbin this week.

item.title: France Begins New Anti-Islamist Sweep in Mali
item.description: France said the operation was coordinated with Malian forces and United Nations peacekeepers to thwart “a resurgence of terrorist movements.”
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: A French soldier north of Gao in April.

item.title: Kenya Assails Coverage of an Attack on a Mall
item.description: Journalists connected with showing a video that appears to show Kenyan forces looting at the Westgate mall have been summoned by the police.
item.dc:creator: By JOSH KRON
item.media:description: Kenyans watched the Westgate mall from afar in September, when a group of militants mounted an attack that left 60 people dead.

item.title: French Fault Banks Over Tax Evasion
item.description: Lawmakers issued a report that blamed a chain of financial players in connection with a flight of revenue estimated at 80 billion euros a year.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
